question.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding translocation of food in plants?

options.text: In food transport the source-sink the relationship is variable depending on the season or the plant's need.
Phloem sap consists of mainly water and sucrose, but other sugars, hormones and amino acids are also translocated through the phloem.
In sugar utilising sink cells, the osmotic pressure must be very high so that they can get water along with sugar from the phloem.
Active transport is required for the process of loading and unloading of sugar.

solution.text: At the source end, sugar is formed, its water potential decreases and water enters the sieve tube osmotically. Hence, turgor pressure increases and at the sink end, osmotic potential decreases. This osmotically generated gradient causes mass or bulk transport between the sink and source.
